header.title: IRISH WITCHCRAFT AND DEMONOLOGY
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, History of Witchcraft

central_thesis: The book aims to be the first comprehensive collection of scattered stories and records of witchcraft in Ireland, arguing that belief in witchcraft did take a fairly firm hold there, though perhaps more muted than elsewhere in Europe, and tracing its historical progression and specific manifestations, particularly among the Anglo-Norman/Protestant population, while also discussing related supernatural phenomena.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER I: SOME REMARKS ON WITCHCRAFT IN IRELAND
structure_content.summary: This chapter introduces the book's premise, challenging the notion that Ireland was exempt from witchcraft. It explores reasons for Ireland's perceived lesser involvement, such as geographical aloofness, the influence of Anglo-Norman invaders, the distinct nature of Celtic beliefs versus Anglo-Norman views on witchcraft (as an offense against God and man), the impact of the Reformation, and a noted absence of witchcraft literature in Ireland. It argues that while less prevalent, witchcraft did exist and was taken seriously, particularly by the Protestant minority, but the turmoil of the period prevented it from maturing as elsewhere. It also highlights the less severe methods of torture and execution compared to the Continent and Scotland, mainly focusing on historical records from Anglo-Norman and Protestant communities.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER II: DAME ALICE KYTELER, THE SORCERESS OF KILKENNY (A.D. 1324)
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides a detailed account of the Kyteler case, the first well-documented witchcraft trial in Ireland. Dame Alice Kyteler, from an Anglo-Norman family, was accused in 1324 by her four husbands' children of denying the Christian faith, sacrificing dismembered animals to a demon named Son of Art, seeking demonic counsel, blasphemously imitating excommunication rituals, and using powders and ointments (made from gruesome ingredients) to cause love, hatred, disease, or death. She was also accused of having carnal knowledge with the incubus Son of Art. Despite attempts by powerful figures like Chancellor Roger Outlawe and Seneschal Sir Arnold le Poer to obstruct Bishop Richard de Ledrede's prosecution, Kyteler fled to England. Her accomplice, Petronilla of Meath, confessed under torture and was publicly burned alive in Kilkenny on November 3, 1324, marking the first instance of death by fire for heresy in Ireland. The chapter also details the subsequent persecution of Kyteler's associates and Bishop de Ledrede's eventual downfall and exile.

This chapter contextualizes the Kyteler case, asserting its uniqueness in early Irish witchcraft records. It notes prior mentions of heresy and unorthodoxy in the Diocese of Ossory around 1317. The chapter discusses other instances of heresy, such as the burning of Adam Dubh in 1327 and two men in Bunratty in 1353, linking them to a wider wave of heresy manifesting as denial of Church doctrine and magical arts. It then touches on historical figures associated with magical powers, like Michael Scot (Archbishop-elect of Cashel, renowned necromancer) and Gerald, fourth Earl of Desmond (the Poet). The chapter also includes an account of an Irish prophetess who foretold King James I of Scotland's assassination in 1437. A sorcery accusation in the 1447 Parliament Rolls suggests earlier, unrecorded instances. It mentions a 1544 inquiry into a witch and a 1578 Kilkenny trial where two witches and a 'blackamoor' were executed. Finally, it details the 1586 Irish Statute against witchcraft, which provided for the death penalty for fatal bewitchment and lesser penalties for non-fatal practices, noting its relative mildness compared to European laws. It also describes the superstition of 'eye-biting witches' harming cattle and the legend of the Enchanted Earl of Desmond.

This chapter documents various magical and supernatural events in Ireland during the early to mid-17th century. It begins with the 1606 trial of John Aston, a clergyman accused of using invocations and conjurations of 'wicked and lying spirits' to find stolen silver and gold and to ascertain the whereabouts of Hugh, Earl of Tyrone. It describes a 1609 case where magical spells were counteracted by a holy relic at Holy Cross Abbey, leading Anastasia Sobechan to vomit pins and cloth. The chapter features the tale of Dr. Alexander Colville, a Doctor of Divinity accused of selling his soul to the Devil for wealth, whom he outsmarted by using a hat with a slit over a kiln-pit to accumulate gold and later extinguishing a candle to delay his due. It also includes an account of John Stewart, who gained knowledge from the King of Fairies, and Reverend Robert Blair's encounter with a man supposedly possessed by a Devil. Strange apparitions in Co. Tipperary (1678) and Portadown (of murdered people) are recounted, along with instances of charmed lives and prophecies by Archbishop James Usher. The chapter concludes with the story of Mr. John Browne and a mysteriously opening locked chest, hinting at a premonition of death.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER V: FLORENCE NEWTON, THE WITCH OF YOUGHAL (A.D. 1661)
structure_content.summary: This chapter presents a detailed account of the 1661 trial of Florence Newton, the 'Witch of Youghal.' Newton was accused of bewitching Mary Longdon and causing the death of David Jones. Longdon testified that Newton's kiss led to violent fits, vomiting needles, pins, and other objects, and being invisibly moved around the house. Newton was also observed to cause Longdon's fits to intensify when brought near her and to spontaneously fall when Newton made certain gestures. During her trial, Newton was tested for her ability to recite the Lord's Prayer (which she struggled with) and had her body probed for insensitive spots. David Jones's widow testified that Newton's kiss through prison grates caused Jones to suffer severe pain and eventually die. The chapter describes the 'water-experiment' contemplated by the Mayor of Youghal for witches. Noteworthy individuals like Valentine Greatrakes (a famous healer) were involved in the proceedings. The author notes the historical value of the account, based on Judge Sir William Aston's notes, as an eye-witness record of a witch-trial in mid-17th century Ireland.

This chapter continues to document diverse supernatural events and magical beliefs. It recounts a humorous tale of Joseph Damer, who outsmarted the Devil in a bargain for gold by using a boot with a removed sole over a hole, leading the Devil to fill a cellar. Another story from Ballinagarde describes Mr. Croker's encounter with the Devil, identified by a cloven hoof. A prominent account details a ghost (James Haddock) who appeared to Francis Taverner, requesting him to ensure his son's rightful inheritance, eventually instigating a lawsuit. The ghost reappeared multiple times, threatening Taverner, who eventually delivered the message, leading to a trial before Bishop Jeremy Taylor. The chapter also describes a witch rescued by the Devil from execution, Dr. Daniel Williams's experience freeing a girl from poltergeist-like disturbances in Dublin, and apparitions seen in the air over Co. Tipperary. It includes cases of bewitchment leading to death, such as Rev. James Shaw and his wife, and a fairy-possessed butler who was seen rising from the ground. Finally, it notes supposed witchcraft in Co. Cork and instances of the Devil appearing at Quaker meetings in Ireland.

This chapter focuses on the case of Mrs. Glover, an Irish-American woman accused of witchcraft in Boston in 1688, which is considered a precursor to the Salem witch trials. Mrs. Glover, described as a 'Scandalous Irish Woman,' was accused by the Goodwin children after one of them became ill following an argument. The children experienced violent fits, physical distortions, and temporary blindness, deafness, and dumbness. Glover was committed after giving a 'Wretched Account of herself,' and her house search revealed 'Images, or Poppets, or Babies, made of Raggs and stuffed with Goat's Hair.' She confessed to tormenting victims by wetting her finger with spittle and stroking these images. During her trial, she could only speak Irish, attributed to a spell, and struggled to recite the Lord's Prayer. She claimed an incubus named her 'Prince' from whom she received wealth. After her execution, the Goodwin children's torments continued, attributed by Glover to others. The chapter notes Cotton Mather's detailed documentation and his belief in the validity of the witchcraft, highlighting how this case influenced subsequent outbreaks of accusations.

This chapter recounts several events related to the supernatural and witchcraft. It begins with a portent during James II's entry into Dublin in 1689, where the mace fell, and the cross on its crown stuck between stones, seen as an ill omen. It then details a 1698 Antrim witch-story where a girl was tormented after consuming a sorrel leaf given by a witch, leading to violent fits and vomiting of various objects like needles, pins, and glass. The witch was apprehended, condemned, and burnt. A traditional version suggests the witch was a persecuted old woman stabbed to death, whose ghost haunted the session-house. The chapter also mentions a Scotch girl delated by the Kirk for using charms (from an Irish wise woman) to discover her future husband. Finally, it presents the Island-Magee witch trial of 1711, the last instance of judicial condemnation for witchcraft in Ireland. Mary Dunbar, the 'afflicted' girl, described invisible torments, mysterious movements of objects, and identified seven women as her tormentors through visions and descriptions. The women were tried, found guilty based on circumstantial evidence (like Mary's descriptions matching Janet Mean's crooked fingers), and sentenced to a year's imprisonment and four times in the pillory. The chapter concludes by mentioning Dr. Francis Hutchinson, a prominent critic of witchcraft belief who later became an Irish Bishop.

structure_content.chapter_title: CHAPTER IX: A.D. 1807 TO PRESENT DAY
structure_content.summary: This final chapter explores the persistence and evolution of magical beliefs in Ireland after formal witch trials ceased. It describes the 1808 Carnmoney witch trial of Mary Butters, who was sought to cure a bewitched cow that produced no butter. Her ritual involved boiling milk with pins and needles, which led to the death of three people by suffocation. Butters was discharged, claiming a 'black man' killed the victims. The chapter includes a ballad satirizing the event. It details a 1871 Newtownards case where a farm-hand used a similar method to banish witches troubling cows. The use of the 'Hand of Glory' by Irish thieves in 1831 to paralyze occupants during a robbery is recounted. A story from the Dublin University Magazine describes air travel via a red cap and twig, ending in a castle in England. Modern instances include a 1911 case where an old-age pensioner was tried for killing another woman she believed to be a witch, and contemporary beliefs in pishogues, bone-setters, and charms for milk-magic, cattle-magic (e.g., hare sucking cows, stealing butter with dew-gathering), disease transference by a 'cailleach,' and the malignant 'burying the sheaf' ritual. The chapter concludes by noting that 'Witchcraft, Inchantment, Sorcery, Magic Arts' remain theoretically recognized in the Irish Commission of the Peace, reflecting persistent underlying superstitions in society despite scientific advancement.

key_concepts.definition: Maleficent magic, often involving pacts with demons, causing harm, disease, or death, or controlling natural phenomena. Seen as an offense against God and man, particularly by Anglo-Norman and Protestant communities in Ireland.

A practice of magical arts, sometimes distinguished from witchcraft as a more 'aristocratic pursuit' involving mastery over the Devil to compel bidding, rather than being Satan's slave. Often conflated with witchcraft in legal and popular discourse.

The study or belief in demons, their appearances (e.g., as animals, incubi, or negroes), and interactions with humans, frequently linked to witchcraft accusations and beliefs about pacts with the Devil for power or wealth.
The power to inflict harm or disease, especially on cattle (e.g., preventing butter churns from producing butter), through a malevolent gaze or unspoken malicious intention.

Celtic superstitious beliefs and minor magical practices, often distinct from the Anglo-Norman/Protestant concept of witchcraft. These include various charms, incantations, or rituals for purposes like butter stealing, healing, or disease transference.
A male demon believed to have carnal knowledge with women, providing them with wealth or other benefits, as seen in the Dame Alice Kyteler case with 'Son of Art'.
A supernatural entity, often appearing in animal form (e.g., greyhound, cat, hairy black dog), that serves a witch or wizard to assist in magical operations, provide information, or inflict harm.

A test for witchcraft where a suspected witch (bound with thumb to opposite great toe) is thrown into water. Sinking (and drowning) establishes innocence, while floating proves guilt, based on the belief that water (as an element of Baptism) rejects a sinner.

A magical tool, traditionally a dried and pickled hand of a hanged criminal, holding a candle made from criminal's fat. It was believed to paralyze all those in a house it entered, preventing them from waking during a robbery.

A malignant charm intended to cause an enemy's slow death. It involves fashioning a human-like figure from a sheaf of wheat, sticking pins into its 'joints' (and a straw heart), and burying it in wet ground (for a quick decay) or dry ground (for a slow decay) near the enemy's house, in the name of the Devil.

An old woman, often associated with traditional, sometimes darker, folk magic in Celtic Ireland, believed to have powers such as the transference of mortal sickness from one person to an unsuspecting passer-by.
A subtle form of bewitchment or inflicting harm, often through a malevolent gaze, a curse, or unspoken ill will, without explicit rituals or physical contact.

practical_system.description: This book primarily functions as a historical documentation and analysis of witchcraft and demonology in Ireland, rather than an operative manual for practitioners. However, it meticulously details the *practices attributed to* accused witches and sorcerers, as well as counter-magical or divinatory methods, offering insight into the historical 'operative side' from a societal perspective. These are presented as historical beliefs and accusations, not as instructions for modern magical practice. The methods described are diverse, reflecting both formal accusations of demonic pacts and folk magic concerning everyday misfortunes like illness or stolen butter.
tools: Dismembered animals (for sacrifice).
Lighted candles (for blasphemous rituals).
Powders, unguents, ointments, fat candles (compounded from specific, gruesome ingredients).
Skull of a decapitated thief (as a vessel for compounding ingredients).
Devil's girdle (worn by accomplices).
Staff (for magical flight).
Holy relic (fragment of the True Cross) and a girdle (for counter-magic).
Bible (for invocations, both forwards and backwards reading).
Riddle (turned for invocations).
Nine black cock feathers (for invocations).
Small stones, needles, pins, horsenails, stubbs, wool, straw (manifested by bewitched victims).
Awl (for testing a witch's skin for insensitivity).
Launce (for testing a witch's skin for bleeding).
Wax image, pins, spit, fire (for death magic).
Silver sixpence (as 'earnest money' from the Devil).
Paper inscribed with St. John's Gospel (for counter-charms).
Images/Poppets/Babies made of rags and stuffed with goat's hair (used by Mrs. Glover).
Girdle (for measuring physical effects of magic).
Pot, sweet milk, unused pins, needles, sods (for cow curing magic).
Hair from cow, thatch from suspect's roof, paper with names, fire coal, sod (for cow curing magic).
Herb (for disease transference by a cailleach).
Sheaf of wheat, pins, straw (for 'burying the sheaf' ritual).
Dead man's hand, candle (components of the 'Hand of Glory').
Red cap, twig (for air travel).
rituals: Denial of Christ's faith for a specific period (year or month) to gain power through sorcery (Kyteler case).
Sacrifice of living animals, dismembered and distributed at crossroads, to a specific 'evil spirit of low rank' named Son of Art (Kyteler case).
Seeking advice and responses from demons through sorcery (Kyteler case).
Blasphemous imitation of Church excommunication: Fulminating sentences with lighted candles against husbands, extinguishing candles, and crying 'Fi! Fi! Fi! Amen!' (Kyteler case).

Compounding powders, unguents, ointments, and fat candles for love, hatred, disease, or death, using ingredients like entrails of cocks sacrificed to demons, horrible worms, dead men's nails, hair, brains, and cerements of unbaptized boys, cooked with incantations over oak-logs in a vessel made from a decapitated thief's skull (Kyteler case).
Carnal knowledge with an incubus demon (e.g., Son of Art, appearing as cat, hairy black dog, or negro) to obtain wealth (Kyteler case).
Sweeping wealth towards one's house: Raking street filth towards a specific door at twilight, murmuring 'To the house of William my sonne Hie all the wealth of Kilkennie towne' (Kyteler case).

Raising the Devil for divination: Drawing a circle, turning a riddle on end (south to north or right to left), holding nine black cock feathers, reading Psalm 51 forwards and Revelation 9:19 backwards to summon the Devil for information (Dr. Colville's servant's method).
Countering magical spells with holy relics: Placing a girdle that touched a fragment of the True Cross around the body, leading to vomiting of cloth and wood (Anastasia Sobechan case).
Healing sores: Thrusting sally-twigs into fire until red-hot, then making circles around the sore without touching, while repeating a charm.
Bewitchment through a kiss or 'overlooking': Imparting ill-will or causing harm by a malevolent kiss or gaze (Florence Newton case).
Death by wax image: Forming a wax image of the victim, having the Devil stick pins into it, and turning it on a spit before a fire while repeating the victim's name (Sir George Maxwell case).
Magic for 'gear, kye's milk, love of man': Arts taught by John Stewart (fairy contactee) for various desires.
Exorcism of demonic possession: Prayer and exhortation to defy Satan (Rev. Robert Blair's method).

Curing bewitched cows (Carnmoney witch): Inmates turn waistcoats inside out and stand by cow's head; pot of sweet milk boiled with three rows of unused pins and three packages of needles; chimney and crevices covered to contain smoke, believed to draw out the witch.

Curing a 'blinked' cow: Pulling three locks of hair (forehead, back, tail, nostrils), writing names of suspected persons (three times), burning hair, thatch from a suspect's roof, and the paper with names on a shovel with fire coal; sod then placed to cow's mouth, licking indicates recovery.
Stealing butter: Gathering dew from long grass while saying 'Come all to me!'
Transferring mortal sickness: A 'cailleach' (old woman) plucks an herb on her knees by a public road, gazing at the first passer-by to transfer the patient's disease to them.

Burying the Sheaf: Saying specific words with one's back to the altar in a chapel, fashioning a human-like figure from a sheaf of wheat with pins in its joints (and a straw heart), and burying it in wet ground (for quick death) or dry ground (for slow death) near the enemy's house in the Devil's name.
Use of the 'Hand of Glory': Employing a dead man's hand with a lighted candle to paralyze house inhabitants during a robbery.
Air travel: Using a red cap and a twig with magic words 'By yarrow and rue, And my red cap, too, Hie over to England!' to fly through the air.

relevant_quotes.text: Seymour proposes that the witch-craze was more muted in Ireland than elsewhere in Europe. Relatively speaking, there appear to have been fewer cases in Ireland. This doesn't mean that the consequences were any less harsh for the accused. In these texts we can see how people exhibiting what we would today consider schizophrenic or senile behavior were vulnerable to being accused of witchcraft.
With our present knowledge we cannot trace its active existence in Ireland further back than the Kyteler case of 1324
They offered in sacrifice to demons living animals, which they dismembered, and then distributed at cross-roads to a certain evil spirit of low rank, named the Son of Art.

The said dame had a certain demon, an incubus, named Son of Art, or Robin son of Art, who had carnal knowledge of her, and from whom she admitted that she had received all her wealth. This incubus made its appearance under various forms, sometimes as a cat, or as a hairy black dog, or in the likeness of a negro (Æthiops), accompanied by two others who were larger and taller than he, and of whom one carried an iron rod.

Petronilla was accordingly condemned to be burnt alive, and the execution of this sentence took place with all due solemnity in Kilkenny on 3rd November 1324, which according to Clyn fell on a Sunday. This was the first instance of the punishment of death by fire being inflicted in Ireland for heresy.

Nor was the punishment of death by fire for witchcraft or sorcery employed to any extent in Ireland. We have one undoubted instance, and a general hint of' some others as a sequel to this. How the two witches were put to death in 1578 we are not told, but probably it was by hanging. Subsequent to the passing of the Act of 1586 the method of execution would have been that for felony.

If she sinks (and drowns, by any chance!) her innocence is conclusively established; if, on the other hand, she floats, her witchcraft is proven, for water, as being the element in Baptism, refuses to receive such a sinner in its bosom.

In the Commission of the Peace the newly-appointed magistrate is empowered to take cognisance of, amongst other crimes, "Witchcraft, Inchantment, Sorcery, Magic Arts," a curious relic of bygone times to find in the twentieth century, though it is more than unlikely that any Bench in Ireland will ever have to adjudicate in such a case.

The owner certainly does not believe in witchcraft or pishogues (or perhaps in anything save himself!), yet he fastens on the radiator a "Teddy Bear" or some such thing by way of a mascot. Ask him why he does it--he cannot tell, except that others do the same, while all the time at the back of his mind there exists almost unconsciously the belief that such a thing will help to keep him from the troubles and annoyances that beset the path of the motorist.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book provides a foundational and unique historical account of witchcraft and demonology in Ireland, challenging the common misconception of Ireland's exemption from the European witch craze. Seymour meticulously compiles scattered records, offering deep insights into the social, religious, and legal contexts of magical belief from the 14th to the early 20th century. Its technical precision in detailing accusations, trials, and folk practices—including specific rituals, tools, and perceived effects—makes it an invaluable resource for understanding the operative side of historical magic within an Irish context. The work highlights the blending of formal witchcraft conceptions (often Anglo-Norman/Protestant) with indigenous Celtic superstitions (pishogues), thereby contextualizing Irish practices within broader Western Esoteric and Occult traditions while emphasizing local distinctiveness and comparative mildness of persecution. It is a critical text for any scholar or practitioner seeking to understand the historical evolution and manifestation of magical systems in a specific geographical and cultural setting.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Academic historians, scholars of folklore, religious studies, sociology of religion, and legal history. Practitioners and researchers of Western Esotericism and Occultism, particularly those interested in historical magical practices, grimoire traditions, demonology, and comparative witchcraft studies. The detailed accounts of operative magic (as accused) and supernatural phenomena also appeal to readers interested in historical paranormal accounts and the social impact of superstition.
